Derek, I think you'=
ve pretty much got it.  As Joe said, at least 
with neuroevolution it is vi=
rtually impossible not to include prior 
knowledge.

So what's going on at =
least in my original point is that two 
algorithms that both take the *same=
* kind of prior knowledge are in 
effect back under NFL with respect to eac=
h other.  Because they both 
can include the same a priori information, the=
 provision of such 
information is not an advantage for one over the other,=
 and 
therefore there is nothing else to allow one to outperform the other =

over all possible problems.

My point was that HyperNEAT allows a new kind=
 of prior knowledge to 
be included that cannot be supplied to previous neu=
roevolution (or 
other ML) methods, which separates it from those algorithm=
s in a way 
that *could* allow it to perform better if used right.  Joe has=
 been 
concerned in part with the "if used right" part, since there is no 
=
theoretical guarantee that the user will supply the right prior 
knwowledge=
.  But at least the opportunity is there.
